awd_titl_txt: The Louis Stokes South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation: A Senior Alliance Enhancing Opportunities to Transition Students Into Successful STEM Pathways
awd_abstract_narration: The Louis Stokes South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation (LS-SCAMP) is designed to increase the quality and quantity of underrepresented minority students (URMs) who complete baccalaureate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines and who successfully transition to pursue advanced graduate STEM degrees. LS-SCAMP is made up of South Carolina State University in collaboration with six Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), five technical colleges and three research institutions in South Carolina. The projects goals are to intensify recruitment initiatives to increase STEM enrollment by 30%, to increase and sustain the STEM baccalaureate degree production by 12% above the Phase I attainment (500 baseline to 800 degree attainment over 5 years), increase the number of LS-SCAMP students who enter graduate school within two years of graduating by 50 percent, develop two summer bridge programs (one academic and one research) for the successful transition of thirty technical college students into STEM baccalaureate degree programs in year one and 150 students over five years and increase the number of students that participate in academic and summer research activities.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Louis Stokes South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation program (LS-SCAMP) is one of the oldest and most successful alliances currently existing in the state of South Carolina. Established in 1992 as a collaborative effort between the National Science Foundation and eight higher education institutions and restructured in 2002, with South Carolina State University becoming the lead institution,  LS-SCAMP now consists of twelve South Carolina institutions including six Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs): Benedict College, Claflin University, Voorhees College, Morris College, Allen University, and inclusive of SCSU; three majority universities: Clemson University -Research I, the University of South Carolina - Research I, the College of Charleston; and three technical colleges: Midlands Technical College, Denmark Technical College, and Orangeburg-Calhoun Technical College.  The primary goal of LS-SCAMP is to increase the quality and quantity of underrepresented minority students who complete baccalaureate degrees in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) disciplines and who successfully transition to pursue advanced graduate STEM degrees. The senior alliance over the past twenty-five years has been successful in providing effective intervention strategies to increase STEM enrollment and baccalaureate degree completion among underrepresented minority students in South Carolina.  

The following outcomes reflect the impact of The Louis Stokes South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation Program (LS-SCAMP) over Phase III (2013-2021):

  • In over twenty-nine years of the program's existence, member institutions have awarded 15,394 STEM degrees and enrolled 124,970 URMs in STEM disciplines (1992-2021). 
  • The state of South Carolina now has 2 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) programs successfully funded (University of South Carolina -2019 and Clemson University- 2021).
  • Alliance institutions initiated the International Research Experiences and provided 23 International Research Experiences in over 4 countries.
  • There were 701 academic year and summer research internships completed by URMs from 2013-2020.
  • There were 242 summer and academic-year bridge participants over Phase III (2014 - 2020).
  • There was a 3.5% increase in URM STEM enrollment at alliance institutions during 2020-2021.  
  • Alliance institutions transferred 331 URM students into STEM during Phase II (2008-2013) Transfer data was only reported for SC State during Phase III (2013-2021)- 282 transfers.
  • There was a 54% increase in URM students enrolled in graduate school during Phase III (2013-2021)- 142 as compared to 92 during Phase II (2008-2013).
  • LS- SCAMP institutions have become the major producers of the STEM baccalaureate degrees awarded (over 64%) annually in the state of South Carolina.
  • LS-SCAMP 2-year technical college partners (Midlands, Denmark, and O-C Tech) enrolled 21% of underrepresented minorities in the state.
  • The LS-SCAMP Undergraduate Science and Engineering Research Conferences have been successfully held over the following project years with a total of 77 undergraduate presenters: 2016- 32 presenters and 2018 - 45 presenters.
  • Sixty (60) profiles of distinguished LS-SCAMP alumni (M.S. and Ph.D.) were published in the 2020 LSAMP Trailblazers Magazine.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/26/2022
Modified by: Judy D Salley
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Louis Stokes South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation program (LS-SCAMP) is one of the oldest and most successful alliances currently existing in the state of South Carolina. Established in 1992 as a collaborative effort between the National Science Foundation and eight higher education institutions and restructured in 2002, with South Carolina State University becoming the lead institution,  LS-SCAMP now consists of twelve South Carolina institutions including six Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs): Benedict College, Claflin University, Voorhees College, Morris College, Allen University, and inclusive of SCSU; three majority universities: Clemson University -Research I, the University of South Carolina - Research I, the College of Charleston; and three technical colleges: Midlands Technical College, Denmark Technical College, and Orangeburg-Calhoun Technical College.  The primary goal of LS-SCAMP is to increase the quality and quantity of underrepresented minority students who complete baccalaureate degrees in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) disciplines and who successfully transition to pursue advanced graduate STEM degrees. The senior alliance over the past twenty-five years has been successful in providing effective intervention strategies to increase STEM enrollment and baccalaureate degree completion among underrepresented minority students in South Carolina.  

The following outcomes reflect the impact of The Louis Stokes South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation Program (LS-SCAMP) over Phase III (2013-2021):

In over twenty-nine years of the program's existence, member institutions have awarded 15,394 STEM degrees and enrolled 124,970 URMs in STEM disciplines (1992-2021). 
The state of South Carolina now has 2 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) programs successfully funded (University of South Carolina -2019 and Clemson University- 2021).
Alliance institutions initiated the International Research Experiences and provided 23 International Research Experiences in over 4 countries.
There were 701 academic year and summer research internships completed by URMs from 2013-2020.
There were 242 summer and academic-year bridge participants over Phase III (2014 - 2020).
There was a 3.5% increase in URM STEM enrollment at alliance institutions during 2020-2021.  
Alliance institutions transferred 331 URM students into STEM during Phase II (2008-2013) Transfer data was only reported for SC State during Phase III (2013-2021)- 282 transfers.
There was a 54% increase in URM students enrolled in graduate school during Phase III (2013-2021)- 142 as compared to 92 during Phase II (2008-2013).
LS- SCAMP institutions have become the major producers of the STEM baccalaureate degrees awarded (over 64%) annually in the state of South Carolina.
LS-SCAMP 2-year technical college partners (Midlands, Denmark, and O-C Tech) enrolled 21% of underrepresented minorities in the state.
The LS-SCAMP Undergraduate Science and Engineering Research Conferences have been successfully held over the following project years with a total of 77 undergraduate presenters: 2016- 32 presenters and 2018 - 45 presenters.
Sixty (60) profiles of distinguished LS-SCAMP alumni (M.S. and Ph.D.) were published in the 2020 LSAMP Trailblazers Magazine.
